p:
In the general population, increased levels of FVIII or FIX are associated with increased risk of thrombosis
112â€“ 117 . Supraphysiological levels of FVIII in the HA study raise safety concerns
114, 115, 118 , since men with hemophilia are not protected from cardiovascular disease and remain at risk of thrombotic complications
118 . In addition, there is no evidence that levels above 50% of normal are associated with pathological bleeding, and hemophilia carriers have decreased mortality due to ischemic heart disease
119 . The relative short-term follow-up of HA patients expressing elevated levels of FVIII prevent firm conclusions on the safety of this finding.
